title: Burglar who wore T-shirt saying 'It's-a me' in photo after being arrested is jailed for 20 weeks
text:
A man wearing a T-shirt with an 'It's-a me' slogan has been arrested for using a stolen bank card to buy groceries.

Andrew Horsman, 37, was pictured straight after his arrest wearing a t-shirt imprinted with the famous words said by iconic mustachioed Nintendo video-game character Mario, 'It's-a-me'.

Horsman, of no fixed abode, was jailed for 20 weeks at York Magistrates' Court after pleading guilty to burglary and fraud on Friday.

Andrew Horsman, 37, (pictured) was pictured straight after his arrest wearing a t-shirt carrying the famous words said by iconic mustachioed Nintendo video-game character Mario, 'It's-a-me'

Horsman, of no fixed abode, was jailed for 20 weeks at York Magistrates' Court (pictured) after pleading guilty to burglary and fraud on Friday

Three days earlier on October 8, Horsman had entered an area of the university campus, to which only students have authorised access, shortly after 11am.

Once inside, he snatched a purse from an unattended bag before removing the bank cards and replacing the purse.

Horsman went on to use one of the cards to buy groceries at a store within the city.

He was arrested on October 11 after being identified from CCTV footage following an investigation by PC Lee Ward of North Yorkshire Police's newly implemented Expedite Team.

Speaking after the hearing, PC Ward said: 'Unfortunately, we see all too often the devastating impact that such crime can have on its victims.

'It is, therefore, very satisfying that someone like Horsman, who has deliberately targeted the city's students, has been given a jail sentence for his crime.

'I hope that his conviction will act as warning to other criminals that we will not tolerate such crime in York and will act quickly to tackle their offending.

'The technology and investigative resources that police have at their disposal is improving all the time and if you do prey on our communities, there is a very good chance that we will catch you and put you before the courts.'
description: Andrew Horsman, 37, was arrested and pictured wearing an 'It's-a-me' slogan T-shirt after he was caught buying groceries with a bank card stolen from a York university campus on October 8.
